sen.j: 御供衆（おともしゅう）とは、足利尊氏の挙兵にお供をして鎌倉から上洛した武将たちのことである。
sen.e: Otomoshu is an attendant group of busho (military commanders) who raised their army and attended the Shogun Takauji ASHIKAGA to go up to the ancient capital Kyoto when the shogun raised his army.
Otomoshu were a group of busho (military commander) attendants who proceeded to the ancient capital of Kyoto from Kamakura and devoted themselves to raising Shogun Takauji ASHIKAGA's army.
sen.cmt: added "Kamakura" information to coincide with the Japanese; fixed grammar to not sound redundant
sen.e: "Otomoshu" were a group of busho (military commander) attendants who proceeded to the ancient capital of Kyoto from Kamakura and devoted themselves to raising Shogun Takauji ASHIKAGA's army.
sen.cmt: 統一リスト（その他 2009/6/29）の指示により、Otomoshu にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: お供をした武将の子孫はこの称号を世襲した。
sen.e: The descendants of the group succeeded the title Otomoshu.
Descendants of the busho who served as attendants in this group succeeded the title of Otomoshu.
Descendants of the busho who served as attendants in this group succeeded the title of Otomoshu.
Otomoshu in Muromachi Shogunate (Japanese feudal government headed by Shogun)
Otomoshu within the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government head by a shogun).
sen.cmt: changed "shogunate" to "bakufu" to be consistent with the word list
sen.e: Otomoshu within the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government head by a shogun).

sen.j: 室町幕府の役職ではなく席次を示していた。
sen.e: In Muromachi Shogunate the title Otomoshu did not indicate the position but the order of precedence.
Rather than being an official post in the Muromachi bakufu, the term was used to indicate class standing.
sen.cmt: "order of precendence" seems too ambiguous to me, so I changed it to "class standing"; fixed grammar
sen.e: Rather than being an official post in the Muromachi bakufu, the term was used to indicate class standing.

sen.j: さらに、大名（守護）の家格を区別していた。
sen.e: And it also differentiated the family status of Daimyo or Shugo (feudal Japanese territorial lord.)
Furthmore, Otomoshu also differentiated from the family status of Daimyo or Shugo (Japanese territorial lord).
Furthermore, Otomoshu also differentiated from the family status of Daimyo or Shugo (Japanese territorial lord).
sen.cmt: Furthmore を Furthermore に修正しました。

sen.j: 御供衆のほかにも、御相伴衆、国持衆、外様衆などがあった。
sen.e: Besides Otomoshu there were several titles such as Oshobanshu (officials who accompanied Shogun), Kunimochishu (one of honorary terms for local governors who were in hereditary vassalage to the Shogun) and Tozamashu (military clans who were not a member the Shogun's family or did not originally support the Shogun.)

In addition to Otomoshu, there were several titles such as Oshobanshu (officials who accompanied the Shogun), Kunimochishu (one of many honorary terms used for locals governors who were heredity vassals of the Shogun) and Tozamashu (military clans who were not related to the Shogun's family or did not originally support the Shogun).

In addition to Otomoshu, there were several titles such as Oshobanshu (officials who accompanied the shogun), Kunimochishu (one of many honorary terms used for local governors who were heredity vassals of the shogun) and Tozamashu (military clans who were not related to the shogun's family or did not originally support the shogun).
sen.cmt: locals governors を local governors に修正しました。Shogun を shogun に修正しました（※）。※ここでは特定の将軍のタイトルとしてではなく、普通名詞的に使用されているものと思われます。よって、統一リスト（「用語統一」2009/06/29「将軍」）の指示により、文頭を小文字に修正しました。

tit.e: A few of the main Otomoshu
A few of the main Otomoshu

sen.e: Yoshioki MIYOSHI
Yoshioki MIYOSHI
Yoshioki MIYOSHI
Nagayoshi MIYOSHI
Nagayoshi MIYOSHI
Nagayoshi MIYOSHI
Takakage ASAKURA (the 10th lord)
Takakage ASAKURA (the 10th lord)
Takakage ASAKURA (the tenth head of the family)
sen.cmt: (10th lord) を (the tenth head of the family) に修正しました。※1 統一リストでは序数が全て英単語で記載されていたため。※2 用語集では「当主」を"family head"と訳されていますが、米国版および英国版のYahooで検索をかけてもこの表記はほとんど全く出てきません。同様の表現で頻出する"the head of the family" の方が容認度が高いものと判断して修正しましたが、この表現における序数のつけ方が不明のため、ご確認願えれば幸いです。

sen.e: Mochinobu ISSHIKI
Mochinobu ISSHIKI
Mochinobu ISSHIKI
Toyoyuki YAMANA
Toyoyuki YAMANA
Toyoyuki YAMANA
UENO clan originally came from MINAMOTO clan
The UENO clan originally came from the MINAMOTO clan
The UENO clan originally came from the MINAMOTO clan
and so on.
etc.
sen.cmt: etc. sounds more natural in an article like this
sen.e: etc.
